title: So why is stopwatch getting nerfed while also affecting Zhonya?
body:
To be honest, I'm just here wondering how this is even worth nerfing and with pretty much the wrong reasons that I see every day.

> "It's broken!"

First off, it's not broken if it works as intended. Broken means it's a bug. Pick a proper word for it. While I understand the meaning behind it, then revive, teleporting, healing, are also broken.

> "It's toxic"

How?

> "My combos get ruined!"

Well boo hoo. Ever heard of something called a counter? Or is that toxic too and want an easy walk at the park?

> "It's 1 click of a button."

EVERYTHING IS AT A CLICK OF A BUTTON. The only difference you're is how many and at what order.

With how the change is going to be, this one is not good. 120 seconds reduced per kill? This will be used even more and make a clown fiesta into a pennywise fiesta. This will just be a cheap version of league of stopwatch. And since Zhonya will be like 15% longer to use, defensive items will be even more lacking especially for mage items let alone the immobile. At least nerf damage on everything. The 1 shot fiestas make stopwatch even worthless anyway.

>Broken means it's a bug. Pick a proper word for it. While I understand the meaning behind it, then revive, teleporting, healing, are also broken.

Something not working properly is just **ONE** definition for "broken", and it's generally not common usage in League. Another, more commonly-used definition for League (and games as a whole) is "overpowered to the point where it ceases to be fair". Something with a 51-52% winrate and 8% pickrate is overpowered, but it's not overpowered *enough* to be considered broken. The more common term for something not functioning correctly in *all* video games is "bugged". A bug can *also* be broken when exploited (such as if Azir's Q suddenly did 10x the damage if he cast it when a soldier died) but that is not always the case (If, say, Azir's Q did 1/10th of its damage if cast when a soldier died).

>First off, it's not broken if it works as intended.

Something can do its intended thing *too* well, or be too good at what it does.

---

Also, you failed to address the actual reasons for nerfs or make an argument against them. You used the wrong definition of a word and made a few strawman arguments. That's it.

> [{quoted}](name=DuskDaUmbreon,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=VpeczAu2,comment-id=000200000000,timestamp=2020-02-12T14:56:28.230+0000)

> A defensive item can still be overtuned.

And Zhonya is not.
With how damage overload there is, Zhonya is not even enough to handle.

There being too much damage=!Specific defensive items being overtuned.

Let's take an extreme example for the sake of having an example: An item that gives 80% damage reduction, no drawbacks and always-on, and that item is just dropped into the pool of items in League right now, with absolutely no other changes to anything. Said item would be objectively overpowered, regardless of whether or not there's too much damage.

A valid argument against nerfing Zhonya's would be talking about its actual usage and winrate statistics. Showing that it only does *average* against AD assassins while being sub-par against everything else would be valid. Showing that it's reasonably good but not overwhelming against AD assassins while being decent but not good against everything else would also be good. Saying that damage is OP so Zhonya's can't be OP is *not* a valid argument.
